message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation suggest a diagnosis of bacterial keratitis, which is best treated with topical antibiotics like ofloxacin. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are not appropriate for this condition. Topical prednisolone is contraindicated in the early stages of bacterial keratitis. Topical ganciclovir is used to treat viral infections like herpes simplex keratitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest that the patient has bacterial keratitis, which is an infection of the cornea. Topical antibiotics are the primary treatment for bacterial keratitis, and ofloxacin is a common choice due to its broad-spectrum coverage. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears can help alleviate symptoms but are not the primary treatment. Topical prednisolone can worsen bacterial infections and is not recommended until the infection is under control. Topical ganciclovir is used to treat viral infections and is not appropriate for this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest bacterial conjunctivitis or keratitis, which can be treated with topical antibiotics. Option B, topical ofloxacin, is the most appropriate choice for treating these conditions. Corticosteroids, such as prednisolone, can exacerbate infections and are contraindicated in this case. Topical ganciclovir is used to treat viral infections, such as herpes, which is not indicated or suggested by the patient’s symptomatology. Artificial tears and topical ketorolac may help relieve symptoms but do not treat the underlying infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has bacterial keratitis, which is an infection of the cornea. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy is topical ofloxacin, which is an anti-infective medication commonly used for bacterial keratitis. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are not effective in treating bacterial infections. Topical prednisolone is a steroid and should not be used in the initial treatment of bacterial keratitis. Topical ganciclovir is used for viral infections and is not appropriate for the treatment of bacterial keratitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of conjunctival injection, an edematous cornea, and a round corneal infiltrate suggests a bacterial infection, which can be treated with topical ofloxacin. Topical prednisolone and ganciclovir are not appropriate for a bacterial infection, and topical ketorolac only helps with pain and inflammation, but does not treat the underlying infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with acute bacterial keratitis, and the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this condition is topical antibiotics such as ofloxacin. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears can help with pain and inflammation, but will not treat the infection. Topical prednisolone can worsen the infection and should not be used in acute bacterial keratitis. Topical ganciclovir is used to treat viral infections and is not appropriate for this patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the patient has bacterial keratitis. Topical ofloxacin is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for bacterial keratitis. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are used for pain relief and dry eye symptoms, respectively. Topical prednisolone is used for inflammation but may exacerbate the infection in this case. Topical ganciclovir is used for viral infections, which is not the case in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a corneal ulcer, most likely caused by bacterial infection. Topical ofloxacin is an appropriate choice for treating bacterial corneal ulcers. Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are not effective against bacterial infections, and topical prednisolone can worsen a bacterial infection. Topical ganciclovir is used to treat viral infections and is not appropriate in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is bacterial keratitis. Topical ofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat bacterial eye infections. Topical ketorolac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug used for eye pain and inflammation, but it wouldn't treat the infection. Topical prednisolone is a steroid that can reduce inflammation but may worsen the infection. Topical ganciclovir is an antiviral used for herpes simplex virus keratitis, which is not the likely diagnosis here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination suggest a corneal abrasion, and option B, topical ofloxacin, is the appropriate pharmacotherapy for bacterial keratitis, which can develop in a corneal abrasion. Option A, ketorolac, may provide pain relief but will not treat the underlying infection. Option C, prednisolone, is contraindicated as it can worsen the infection. Option D, ganciclovir, is used in the treatment of herpes simplex virus eye infections, which is not the likely cause of this patient’s symptoms.
